Award.AwardTitle: P2C2: Hydroclimatic response of the tropical Pacific to past changes in mean state: Observations and synthesis
Award.AbstractNarration:
How will El Ni単o events change as the climate changes? There is currently no consensus on the answer to this question from climate change projections for the 21st century. Yet even small changes in El Ni単o event strength, duration or frequency have significant effects, both in the US and internationally, on water resources, wildfires, agriculture and ecosystems. This project will contribute new observations and analysis of El Ni単o/Southern Oscillation (ENSO) activity during two past time intervals for which there are very few data from the tropical Pacific, yet for which the global climate is thought to have been relatively warm and relatively cold, respectively. Results will be compared to climate simulations for the same periods, so that we can better understand if, how and why global climate change can cause changes in El Ni単o activity. The project will also provide mentored, international, collaborative, and multidisciplinary training for a PhD student and an undergraduate researcher, including educational, outreach and dissemination activities. It will contribute inputs for modeling the interactions between people, fisheries and climate in a location and region with a rich archaeological history of pre-modern settlement, voyaging and exploration. These studies, which are beyond the scope of this project, may ultimately help us understand how societies have and may adapt to past and future climate change.

Specifically, paired oxygen isotope and Sr/Ca data series will be developed from existing and diagenetically screened coral samples dating to the Little Ice Age (LIA) and Medieval Climate Anomaly (MCA) time windows from Aitutaki, southern Cook Islands (18.85S, 159.79W). Preliminary analysis suggests interannual variations in present day (PD) coral oxygen isotopic composition from the region primarily reflect sea surface salinity (SSS) variability resulting from changes in the position and strength of the South Pacific Convergence Zone associated with ENSO activity. In conjunction with other hydroclimatic and oceanographic paleoclimate data available for these time windows and the PD, the research team will test whether there were differences in interannual event amplitude and recurrence interval in the LIA and MCA relative to the PD. The team will compare the results to those obtained from similarly sampled, PMIP3-compliant physical climate simulations with both complete and single external radiative forcings. Comparison of observations and simulations, within the context of their uncertainties, will be used to assess if and the extent to which the observed hydroclimatic response is forced or unforced, and by what mechanisms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the past 150 years, atmospheric greenhouse gas concentrations are changing, and it has been hypothesized that this may also cause ElNino and the Southern Oscillation (ENSO) to change as well, withpotential societal impacts on water resources, agriculture and fisheries in the tropics and worldwide.  


In this project, a collaboration between US, New Zealand, and Australian scientists, we collected data from fossil corals that reflect ENSO activity during the early part of the millennium, about 850-1100 years ago.  This was a time during which we observe from ice core records that greenhouse gas concentrations were not changing as they are today.  In addition, there is no evidence from ice core records of other drivers of climate change, such as explosive volcanic events, during this time.


We found that the size and recurrence of ENSO events at this time, asindicated in the coral data we collected, was indistinguishable from that of the past 150 years, as observed in the same type of data for the present from a nearby location.  Since the present is a time of increasing greenhouse gas concentrations, and there have been several explosive volcanic events, we infer that variations in ENSO activity we observe today are not primarily caused by increasing greenhouse gas concentrations, but could arise from the nature of ENSO itself.
